I thought the LB's missed a lot of tackles, neither did they attempt to make any tackles.  They allowed to many catches and runs waltz right by them. Levy and Tahir had a good season last year.  Levy leading the league in tackles last year.  I would like to see more intensity from Deandre Levy.  He's got to convince me he can stay fierce at linebacker.  I want to see him attack whoever has the football. If he does that then he will be a killer.   I also thought they were slow as hell in zone plays.  We need to see a little more hustle and bustle when they are in zone plays. I think the LB's and DB's need to read and get to  the ball more quickly.  QB's were picking them apart (Tom Brady, Aaron Rogers now they play Payton, Colin, Aaron, Breese and Russle this year).  Especially when they were playing man to man coverage.  The push from the D- line last year really helped the LB's improve with their assignments (now they have Ngata who now knew the Ravens D? are you for real?).  If they continue with that we will see some major improvements from not only the LB's but from the entire defense. They would most certainly see more picks and sacks. Overall I think this stable of LB's can continue to spark some magic.  This defense is most certainly promising.

data.name: Caldwell: Sam Martin's best is yet to come

data.message: Martin has talent but late in games he chokes up.  Martins 4th quarter splits are by far his worst. Plus he has cost the Lions 2 games in 2 years with late shanked punts without pressure.                                                       A third late game blunder is when he kicked off OB in the game for the title at GB that led to a Packer score. Lions do not need a great punter just a guy who can punt late in close games. Punters who did what Martin did against Dallas are usually released the next day.
Lets not talk about the potential of a punter

data.message: Top 3 I think people are gonna be real surprised by the additions of Ngata and Abdullah not to mention the returning players who were already on fire

http://www.freep.com/story/sports/nfl/lions/2015/07/21/detroit-lions-stafford-ranking/30468637/

The loss of Suh will not knock the Lions out of the top 10 in defense. They added Ngata and Tulloch will be back. I have a feeling a lot of you already forgot how good Tulloch is. Ngata is a better run stopper than Suh, and Tulloch is also a beast when it comes to stopping the run. This will also be the 2nd year under Teryl Austin, who by the way is one of the best DCs in the NFL.........If you really think the loss of Suh is going to make the defense go from #2 to #15 or worse, please stop talking......Levy, Tulloch, Ansah, Jones, Ngata, Quin, Slay, Whitehead, Ihedigbo. Enough said.
They will probably be borderline top 10, still solid.

Your overlooking factors such as pregame planning bc of Suh and Fairley... Fairley provided intimidation, force the OC to design conservatively, QB pressures and stout short yardage defensive respect like we havent seen since the Alex Karras days (40 years ago). Lions have no chance of getting to Superbowl in respect to losing this game winning dual. Stafford and Johnson cant get it done--they should of got rid of both of them. Built around Suh and Fairley... They will be lucky to be a 500 team this year.
The defense will still be good, but that's a rough stretch to start out. If the run D improves, Minnesota will be easier to beat, and they have a chance to make the playoffs again.

If Stafford could live up to his "Number 1 pick overall" and put points on the board early they might have a chance...but when he flounders this puts pressure on the defense, they are on the field too long and before you know it it is 24-3 at the half....and then Stafford gets his usual garage  yards and they lose 30-27.....

There is never any logic behind the hate for Stafford. 1. They were in their first year in a new complicated offensive system. 2. The OLine was one of the worst in the NFL. Can't go through all your reads and make perfect passes when you're getting sacked/hit every play. 3. The WRs and TEs were injured and missed a big chunk of the season. Who's he supposed to throw the ball too? 4. The WRs lead the league in drops for the millionth year in a row. So when he does make a perfect pass, it gets dropped. 5. They had no running game. Therefore, defenses played against the pass all game every game.....We all seen what he can do with a healthy OLine and when he is given time to throw. 5,000+ yards 40+ TDs.....I'd love to see a Stafford hater try to argue against anything I just said. I'm actually begging someone too.....They won't be able too.

I know that at this point, Matt Stafford is on the hot seat. I am neither a Stafford slappy, nor am I a hater. He has to be more consistent, he has to make difficult throws look routine, and he has to play better against good competition. He doesn't suck but he is not the Second coming. 
Blaming him after he came to a winless team and has had to try to win while our front office has squandered most of our draft picks, is beyond silly. He finally had a good defense and we won 11 games, go figure. If we continue to support him by playing good defense, running the ball some, and staying healthy, I believe that he is good enough to get us to a Super Bowl. 
He has all of the talent needed, he has weapons, has a line, has talent on the other side of the ball  and we can now see if he is capable of continuing to improve. He's not leaving, he's committed to Detroit, and we need to give him his chance to show us why we made him a #1 Overall. Go Lions!

data.name: Five numbers that need to change in 2015

data.message: Less sacks, penalties and drops. More rushing yards, better throws and most importantly more points on the board....The offense is way too good to only be averaging 20 points a game. Hopefully another year in the new offensive system and a healthier OLine will help this offense hit their full potential. If it weren't for the defense last season, the Lions probably wouldn't have even won 5 games.
The bottom line, Stafford has got to be better if team will improve.  Quarterbacks are paid to win games and that means putting team on his back at times.

A lot hinges on the O-line; Stafford's time in the pocket, rushing yards, the offense's overall performance. 
Stafford, then, needs to up his game, too. 
I think this could be a special year; the offense has weapons, the defense looks pretty good, and we have veteran leadership.

data.name: Offseason workouts important to Matthew Stafford

data.message: Last year Stafford had a PRETTY GOOD (not great) year to be in the first year of an offense, have no run game, no blocking, injuries to key players, and only have 2 consistent receivers. You can only imaginge what he can do in year 2, with a new line, new weapons in the backfield, and a new and improved Ebron along with Lance Moore and a healthy Calvin.

Matthew Stafford is the best qb to wear a LIONS uniform on my lifetime. That's a pretty long time considering I'm in my 50's. Wins and losses are a team state not just on the qb. I've watched nearly every game he's played in. Thank God for Direct tv and the Sunday Ticket. Give him a pocket to pass from and I believe he passes with the best of them. How many qb's have 5000yrds in a season?
Payton Manning, Drew Brees, Aaron Rodgers, all three have something in common. Zero playoff wins before their 26th birthday. Have patience people.

In 2013 injuries left the team with almost no receivers for him to throw the ball to. Durham was the team's number one receiver. Passer rating isn't a good measurement for a qb's performance as it relies heavily on the receivers to do their part as much as the qb. Case in point, interceptions drive passer rating way down. The difference between winning and losing, consistently,  comes down to TEAMWORK!!!!! Especially in football. That means coaching, training and management.  Stafford is alright. Potentially, great. So what? Suh was demonstrably great. So what? Still no Super Bowl Ring.  Teamwork,  folks.

data.name: Charlie Sanders: Hall of Fame player, Hall of Fame person

data.message: R.I.P. Charlie Sanders...I have never looked upon a professional athlete as a role model other than Mr. Sanders, as a young kid many years ago, I remember that some of the Detroit Lions were going to various schools to help raise money by playing basketball games. At one game at Lakeville Mr. Sanders was one of those players, after the game all the kids stormed around the players for handshakes, me being a puny shy kid I was ousted out of the way, when I heard this booming voice saying " I want to shake your hand" It was Mr. Sanders pointing to me, walking past the other kids to come over and shake my hand, I have never forgotten that moment. Mr. Sanders was a class act and a gentleman who cared for others.
He was a great player for the Lions!  Sorry to hear this.
I was fortunate enough to have met Charlie Sanders at a Super Bowl party in 2014.  The man was a class act, on and off the field.
A Class Act of a Man, a Team Player, a Roll Model, on and off the Field and for Detroit, He will be missed this fall
Lions legend and all around great guy. Always involved in the community. He will be missed!!

My heart thoughts and prayers go out to the Sanders family and all of Detroit the state of Michigan and One Pride Nation!!!! We lost not only a hall of fame but a great man father husband friend mentor man of God and Icon. We will miss you Charlie Sanders. Thank you for all that you brought to this world and the lives of those you touched.
